questions.question: What is Harry Bittering's main emotion in the first half of the story?

choices.answer: He is afraid of the Martian environment.
He feels safe on Mars.
He is excited to live on Mars.
He is annoyed with the other Earth people.

questions.question: What prevents the family from returning to Earth?

choices.answer: It costs too much to return to Earth.
Atomic war breaks out on Earth
The rocket that Harry builds does not work.
The other humans talk them out of leaving.

questions.question: What is Mr. Bittering's first clue that the world is changing?

choices.answer: Peach blossoms become green and grass becomes purple.
His children adopt Martian names.
His children's eyes turn a golden color.
The cows grow a third horn.

questions.question: How does Mr. Bittering cope with his fears about living on Mars?

choices.answer: He tries to build a rocket and concentrates on his work.
He investigates Martian ruins.
He moves his family to a Martian villa.
He encourages his family to change their names.

questions.question: Describe the Bittering family at the conclusion of the story.

choices.answer: They realize they have to live on Mars and are unhappy.
They are physically different but still act like humans.
They are completely changed into Martians.
They are eager to return to Earth since the war is over.

questions.question: What evidence from the story shows that space rockets can travel much faster than they can today?

choices.answer: The trip to Mars covered 60 million miles.
Harry thought he could build a rocket by himself.
The daily newspapers from Earth are delivered to Mars every morning.
Harry wanted to return to Earth immediately.

questions.question: From which perspective is this story told?

choices.answer: First person
Second person
Third person
Fourth person

questions.question: How did the humans learn to speak Martian?

choices.answer: They took classes.
Their human brains gradually turned into Martian brains.
They learned Martian from hearing other humans speak it.
They heard the Martians speak it.

questions.question: What does the constant wind on Mars most likely represent?

choices.answer: Mr. Bittering's sadness when he cannot return to Earth
The hot weather on Mars that disturbs the Earth people
The destruction of the Earth's people's settlement on Mars
The power of the environment to change the Earth people

questions.question: The Martian air might draw his soul from him as marrow comes from a white bone.

choices.answer: Simile
Metaphor
Personification

questions.question: What is a major theme (message) in the story?

choices.answer: Government should look to other planets to meet our needs.
Humans are generally open-minded and peaceful.
Change is unavoidable in the end.
Far-off worlds can be anything people imagine them to be.

questions.question: At the end of the story, what is the attitude of the lieutenant who arrived?

choices.answer: He finds the environment on Mars unappealing.
He likes the Martians and thinks they are peaceful.
He blames the Martians for disappearance of settlers.
He is afraid of the Martians.

questions.question: "The tissues of his body drew tight like he was standing at the center of a vacuum."

choices.answer: Simile
Metaphor
Personification

questions.question: A river of wind submerged the house.

choices.answer: Simile - wind is like a river
Metaphor - wind is a house
Metaphor - wind is a powerful river
Simile - the house is underwater

questions.question: What was the reaction of the men to Harry's announcement that he was going to build a rocket?

choices.answer: They thought it would be a lot of work
They got angry
They thought it was funny
They wanted to help

questions.question: "Rubber tires upon which children had swung long ago...suspended like stopped clock pendulums..."

choices.answer: The rubber tire swings are peeling due to the sun.
The rubber tire swings swing back and forth.
The rubber tire swings are too hot to play on.
The rubber tire swings are no longer used.

questions.question: When the characters move to the Martian villas, why did they leave all their earthly possessions behind?

choices.answer: They were too weak to move it.
There was no room in the villas for it.
They had created Martian clothes and furniture instead.
They had no use for it.

questions.question: What is the difference between scary and terrifying?

choices.answer: Scary suggests a feeling that is imaginary.
Terrifying suggests a much more powerful feeling of fear.
Terrifying suggests a sense of fun and adventure.
Scary is a feeling; terrifying is an emotion.

questions.question: What is the strongest evidence that the humans have completely turned into Martians?

choices.answer: They only eat Martian-grown food
They moved into the Martian ruins
They have no memory of ever being human
They no longer wanted their possessions from Earth

questions.question: Based on the very end of the story, what do you think will happen to future generations of humans who travel to Mars?

choices.answer: They will eventually become Martians.
They will declare war on the Martians and take over the planet.
They will learn to live peacefully with the Martians.
They will lose interest in Mars and return to Earth.
